strategy: Apply a deep neural network with a fully connected architecture (e.g., 3-5 hidden layers with 128 neurons each) and use batch normalization and dropout regularization. Instead of polynomial features, extract domain-relevant engineered features such as log-transformed areas, ratio of garage to living area, and year-benchmarked age of the house. Use early stopping during training based on validation R² to prevent overfitting. This approach can capture complex non-linear interactions and high-order dependencies that traditional tree models might miss.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder, StandardScaler
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from xgboost import XGBRegressor
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
import warnings

# Load data

test_df = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

categorical_columns = X_train.select_dtypes(include=['object']).columns.tolist()

# Fill missing values in numerical columns with median

X_val[numerical_columns] = X_val[numerical_columns].fillna(X_val[numerical_columns].median())

        X_train[col] = X_train[col].fillna(mode_val[0])

        X_val[col] = X_val[col].fillna(mode_val[0])

        X_train[col] = X_train[col].fillna('Unknown')
        X_test[col] = X_test[col].fillna('Unknown')
        X_val[col] = X_val[col].fillna('Unknown')
